intro: Brachionidium cruziae, commonly known as the Brazilian water flea, is a freshwater copepod belonging to the family Diaptomidae. It is characterized by its small, transparent body and a distinctive elongated shape, with a prominent cephalothorax and a segmented tail. This species is typically found in slow-moving or still freshwater environments, such as ponds and lakes. Brachionidium cruziae plays a vital role in aquatic ecosystems as a primary consumer, feeding on algae and detritus. Its presence is often used as an indicator of water quality in ecological studies.
